titlestmt.subtitle: A Guide to the collection at the Connecticut Historical Society
titlestmt.author: Compiled by CHS Staff

bioghist.head: Historical Sketch
bioghist.p: The Garden Club of Hartford was founded on March 16, 1916 by eight women: Mrs. James P. Andrews, Miss Frances Beach, Mrs. John H. Buck, Mrs. Albert s. Cook, Miss Bertha Dennis, Mrs. Robert W. Gray, Mrs. Robert W. Huntington, and Mrs. Samuel O. Prentice. Mrs. Prentice was the first President and Mrs. Gray the first Secretary and Treasurer. The initiation fee was $2.00 and dues were $1.00. In 1920 the Garden Club of America (founded 1913) admitted the Hartford club as a member.

The Garden Club of Hartford has been active in the community in civic projects since it’s founding. They have contributed their time and have raised money to effect their goals of beautification, conservation, promotion of gardening, and scholarships and fellowships. Funds have been raised by plant sales, flea markets, auctions, dances, and publications. The Old State House has been their largest project. The restoration of the Sunken Garden at Hill-Stead Museum was completed in 1988.

The Club has grown from eight original members to 62 active members in 1988, with 29 members in other categories. Meetings are still held at members houses as originally conceived, as well as at arboretums and other places of interest to learn about such things as plant propagation, pest control, pruning, etc. Members visit fellow members’ gardens, enter and attend flower shows, and keep active in the community.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The records are arranged in ten series. Series I consists of organizational records including articles of incorporation, tax exempt certificates, and minutes of meetings. Series II contains records of projects and awards. These include civic projects, flower shows, etc. The Club’s publications are organized in Series III while photographs can be found in Series IV. In consecutive order, the final series contain clippings and scrapbooks; questionnaires and answers; miscellaneous materials; records and publications of the Federated Garden Clubs of Connecticut; records and publications of the Garden Club of America; and notices, circulars and other published materials from assorted gardening organizations.

The arrangement is chronological. The minutes in Series I contain supplemental material relating to the year’s activities, including correspondence, financial statements, and issues of the Trumpet Vine. The Club continues to add to this collection as they purge inactive files. Additions are added in new boxes after the last numbered box. No attempt is made to integrate new materials into those already processed. However, the new materials are organized into the same Series and are arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on access to the collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Use of the material requires compliance with the Connecticut Historical Society's Research Center regulations.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Item, Collection Title, Collection number (Box #, Folder #). Connecticut Historical Society, Hartford, Connecticut.

processinfo.head: Processing Details
processinfo.p: Collection was initially processed by Barbara H. Newell in 1988. Additional processing by Barbara E. Austen.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: The collection is open. Additional material is expected.
